oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>BACKGROUND:<jats:italic>Nocardia</jats:italic>species are rare, opportunistic organisms that cause disease in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised individuals.</jats:p><jats:p>OBJECTIVE: To investigate the clinical presentations of various<jats:italic>Nocardia</jats:italic>infections based on the 16S ribosomal RNA gene of the isolate, as well as related risk factors and susceptibility patterns to antimicrobial agents</jats:p><jats:p>METHODS: Thirteen patients with a diagnosis of nocardiosis were included in the present study. Seven<jats:italic>Nocardia</jats:italic>species were identified by 16S ribosomal RNA. Susceptibility testing was performed using six antimicrobial agents.</jats:p><jats:p>RESULTS: Five patients were immunocompromised, and eight were immunocompetent with predisposing factors including cystic fibrosis, tuberculosis and ophthalmic infections.<jats:italic>Nocardia</jats:italic>caused pulmonary infections in eight patients (61.5%), invasive systemic infections in three patients (23%) and local (ophthalmic) infections in two patients (15.4%). In the patients with pulmonary disease, nocardiosis was caused by six species (<jats:italic>Nocardia cyriacigeorgica</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>Nocardia otitidiscaviarum</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>Nocardia farcinica</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>Nocardia carnea</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>Nocardia testacea</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>Nocardia asiatica)</jats:italic>. The seventh species identified in the present study was<jats:italic>Nocardia crassostreae.</jats:italic></jats:p><jats:p>DISCUSSION:<jats:italic>N crassostreae</jats:italic>is a multidrug-resistant organism that was reported to be an emerging human pathogen causing invasive nocardiosis in a patient with non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.<jats:italic>N farcinica</jats:italic>was isolated from blood in a patient with breast cancer. None of the<jats:italic>Nocardia</jats:italic>isolates were resistant to linezolid. One<jats:italic>N otitidiscaviarum</jats:italic>isolate was a multidrug-resistant organism. All patients in the present study were treated with the appropriate antibiotics and their condition resolved without further sequelae.</jats:p><jats:p>CONCLUSIONS: The present study is the first report on<jats:italic>N crassostreae</jats:italic>as a human pathogen. The detection of multidrug-resistant species necessitate molecular identification and susceptibility testing, and should be performed for all<jats:italic>Nocardia</jats:italic>infections. Nocardiosis manifests various clinical features depending on the<jats:italic>Nocardia</jats:italic>species and underlying conditions.</jats:p>
